text: Hi

Alright! We'll revise a few concepts before going ahead!
<@U56JCBFA9> define a *Relational Database*
I'm hoping you guys don't sleep :stuck_out_tongue: There's lots of coding in this session!
Kindly tell the answer!
a relational DB stores data in the form of tables
Looks like ma'am is busy at the moment
Okay
It is based on a schema - which includes the name of the table and different column names
<@U56DHFD99> WOuld you kindly remind us what is a Primary Key?
<@U55UC8R09> correct!
<@U55UB6X9P> Kindly tell us what is a Foreign Key and the difference between a Primary Key and a Foreign Key
Yeah, A primary key is a unique key which identifies an instance. It is different for different instances.

Umm that is right <@U56DHFD99> but in simple terms every table in your relational database will have a column which is in most cases called ID which will uniquely identify each and every row in that table
Foreign key is mainly used for creating/indetifying relations while primary key is used for uniquely to identify a instance
We'll talk about this in a bit of detail today
<@U55UB6X9P> again correct but in simple terms foreign key is basically the primary key of any other table!
No need to be so accurate on the definitions! :stuck_out_tongue:
ok:sweat_smile:
<@U55UDASSV> can we have two primary keys in a particular instance/table?
<@U579Y5A7Q> can we have two or more foreign key columns in a table?
<@U57A20DSS> tell me which SQL Version are you running?
sorry internet connection went off
yes.. since a column has many rows. i think
I think you can have 2 columns that uniquely identify a record. But its called an alternate key
<@U55UJ9MH7> you're familiar with MySQL right?
anumeha29: Chill da!

no
<@U55UDASSV> correct
<@U579Y5A7Q> yes you can have primary keys of various other tables in different columns that's why multiple foregin keys can be present!

file.name: How_to_insert_values_in_the_table.php
file.title: How to insert values in the table
file.preview_highlight:
INSERT INTO students (id, name, age) 
VALUES (1, 'Salman Shah', 18);
SELECT * FROM students;

initial_comment.comment: Copy paste this command and after understanding what it does add your own name to it as well.

college IS NULL;

text: Another thing is that the keyword *WHERE* is basically the conditional statement here!
So all conditions are added after the WHERE statement

Where we did not update the value of the field college
@all has anyone heard  of REGEX?
<@U56H3SYJG> yes basically it's the default value that is assigned by MySQL to a particular column value

regular expressions ?

<@U56JCBFA9>
using LIKE command, we can find rows where certain pattern is observed ?
